seq.description: Property.  Standard metadata for higher-level stamped data types.  This is generally used to communicate timestamped data  in a particular coordinate frame.   sequence ID: consecutively increasing ID

stamp.description: Property. Two-integer timestamp that is expressed as:  * stamp.sec: seconds (stamp_secs) since epoch (in Python the variable is called 'secs')  * stamp.nsec: nanoseconds since stamp_secs (in Python the variable is called 'nsecs')  time-handling sugar is provided by the client library

frame_id.description: Property. Frame this data is associated with

Two-integer timestamp that is expressed as:  * stamp.sec: seconds (stamp_secs) since epoch (in Python the variable is called 'secs')  * stamp.nsec: nanoseconds since stamp_secs (in Python the variable is called 'nsecs')  time-handling sugar is provided by the client library

frame_id.description: Property. Frame this data is associated with

x.description: Property.  This represents a vector in free space.  It is only meant to represent a direction. Therefore, it does not  make sense to apply a translation to it (e.g., when applying a  generic rigid transformation to a Vector3, tf2 will only apply the  rotation). If you want your data to be translatable too, use the  geometry_msgs/Point message instead.
Property.  This represents an orientation in free space in quaternion form.

If you want your data to be translatable too, use the  geometry_msgs/Point message instead.

link_name.description: Property.  The CollisionObject will be attached with a fixed joint to this link

stamp.description: Property. frame_id.description: Property. Frame this data is associated with

x.description: Property.  This contains the position of a point in free space
Property.  This represents an orientation in free space in quaternion form.

id.description: Property.  The id of the object (name used in MoveIt)

key.description: Property. ################################################# OBJECT ID #########################################################  Contains information about the type of a found object. Those two sets of parameters together uniquely define an  object  The key of the found object: the unique identifier in the given db

db.description: Property.  The db parameters stored as a JSON/compressed YAML string. An object id does not make sense without the corresponding  database. E.g., in object_recognition, it can look like: "{'type':'CouchDB', 'root':'http://localhost'}"  There is no conventional format for those parameters and it's nice to keep that flexibility.  The object_recognition_core as a generic DB type that can read those fields  Current examples:  For CouchDB:  type: 'CouchDB'  root: 'http://localhost:5984'  collection: 'object_recognition'  For SQL household database:  type: 'SqlHousehold'  host: 'wgs36'  port: 5432  user: 'willow'  password: 'willow'  name: 'household_objects'  module: 'tabletop'

type.description: Property.  Define box, sphere, cylinder, cone  All shapes are defined to have their bounding boxes centered around 0,0,0.  The type of the shape

weight.description: Property.  The weight of the attached object, if known

is_diff.description: Property.  Flag indicating whether this scene is to be interpreted as a diff with respect to some other scene  This is mostly important for handling the attached bodies (whether or not to clear the attached bodies  of a moveit::core::RobotState before updating it with this message)

robot_model_name.description: Property.  The name of the robot model this scene is for

scale.description: Property.  scaling to apply to the link

frame_id.description: Property. Frame this data is associated with

binary.description: Property.  Flag to denote a binary (only free/occupied) or full occupancy octree (.bt/.ot file)

id.description: Property.  Class id of the contained octree

resolution.description: Property.  Resolution (in m) of the smallest octree nodes

is_diff.description: Property.  Flag indicating whether this scene is to be interpreted as a diff with respect to some other scene

plan_only.description: Property.  If this flag is set to true, the action  returns an executable plan in the response but does not attempt execution

look_around.description: Property.  If this flag is set to true, the action of planning &  executing is allowed to look around (move sensors) if  it seems that not enough information is available about  the environment

look_around_attempts.description: Property.  If this value is positive, the action of planning & executing  is allowed to look around for a maximum number of attempts;  If the value is left as 0, the default value is used, as set  with dynamic_reconfigure

max_safe_execution_cost.description: Property.  If set and if look_around is true, this value is used as  the maximum cost allowed for a path to be considered executable.  If the cost of a path is higher than this value, more sensing or  a new plan needed. If left as 0.0 but look_around is true, then  the default value set via dynamic_reconfigure is used

replan.description: Property.  If the plan becomes invalidated during execution, it is possible to have  that plan recomputed and execution restarted. This flag enables this  functionality

replan_attempts.description: Property.  The maximum number of replanning attempts

replan_delay.description: Property.  The amount of time to wait in between replanning attempts (in seconds)
